ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Alternative SharpNEAT Progress form
ygData.msgSnippet: Thanks Mike, this looks really nice. I see you attached some code as well so maybe I ll take a look at integrating this into the main project, it should be

Subject: Re: [neat] Alternative SharpNEAT Progress form
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=127853030; y=js954ISUYaUEnmD0w2JqwCMaYqIkAd29PlbPF3zzHnxhcXHX4Az2
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Thanks Mike, this looks really nice. I see you attached some code as 
well so maybe I'll take a look at integrating this into the main 
project, it should be easy enough. Oh personally I quite like having 
more than one line on a graph where the two values are related somehow - 
it makes it easier to see how the values affect each other and/or how 
they are related, e.g. # of species and compat. threshold, or 
comlplexity and evals/sec. Having said that I see you have put those two 
particular pairings in graphs that are vertically alligned, which makes 
it pretty easy to see actually.

Some other stuff you may not have picked up on. There was some work to 
break the experiment code into seperate binaries and to attach them at 
run time with a config file - which in itself may not be that 
interesting to you, but there is also a mechanism for specifying 
experimnent prameters such as data file paths within teh config file. I 
can't remember if I got round to releasing this yet - anyway it might be 
useful for you.

On a more forward looking note, I also started completely revising the 
whole code base and re-writing it to make it far more flexible to code 
against (e.g. plug-inable genome representations and associated decoded 
'phenome' classes). This is heavily using templates (generics in 
.Net2/Java world) and was makign good progress, right up to the point I 
got distracted :(

Right now I'm acquiring some stock market data (london stocks only) via 
a http/website ripper/reader type program and I'm feeling motivated by 
your work into putting together my own simple analysis experiment using 
the existing code base, so work on the new stuff will probably have to 
wait some more. Actually I've already hacked together some very simple 
non-NEAT parameter optimisation type experiments over stock data with 
interesting results, and I have actually made a little money, which is 
the main reason I got sidelined - and no I haven't been spending it on 
fast cars/women if that's what you were thinking ;)  This is little more 
than traditional graphing/analysis but with some param optimisation 
thrown in, so there is much room for improvement. It's also based on 
analysing shares that I'd already hand picked as being undervalued, but 
I think that is a pretty sound strategy to be starting from (as is 
shorting overvalued shares).

My initial plan is to use both price and trade volume data. Although the 
trade direction (buy vs sell) isn't officially available, most web 
financial web sites determine this in real time by comparing against the 
current bid/offer spread, this can be horribly wrong some days but that 
in itself is a symptom of a specific situation where the spread is very 
narrow. So I think there is useful info in this data even in this 
slightly corrupted form. Certainly I've learned from my trading so far 
that the price by itself is only a small part of the picture, especially 
where trading is through old fashioned market makers who set the price 
rather than the more modern automated SETS system - which system is in 
use for agiven share is also going to be pretty important as well I think.

That's enough banter for now - this is all vaguely to do with NEAT, honest!

Colin.

mikewoodhouse wrote:

>I've uploaded a file showing the alternative ProgressForm I hacked
>together for use within SharpNEAT. The code is relatively trivial -
>I'm scarcely pushing the ZedGraph control and there's almost no logic
>there, but the GIF might be slightly more interesting. I thought it
>was only fair for Colin to see what I've done to his baby...
>
>Mike
